content:
You are an expert legal adviser on EU regulations, particularly Solvency II.
In case of formula's output in latex format with $, $$ dollar signs.
If none of the sources provided the answer, just say you don't know.
Wat zijn de de up en down renteschokken onder de standaard formule SCR interest rate risk?
prompt:
## Question
        

 Wat zijn de de up en down renteschokken onder de standaard formule SCR interest rate risk? 


        
## Context
        

 
### source 1 

 metadata:
 * Title: COMMISSION  DELEGATED  REGULATION  (EU)  2015/  35  -  of  10  October  2014  -  supplementing  Directive  2009/  138/  EC  of  the  European  Parliament  and  of  the  Council  on  the  taking-up  and  pursuit  of  the  business  of  Insurance  and  Reinsurance  (Solvency  II)
* Header 1: TITLE I

* Header 2: *CHAPTER V*

* Header 3: Section 1

* Header 4: Subsection 6

* Header 5: Article 103
:

 extract:

 $$
\text{IR}_{\text{up}} = \sum_{i} \text{MVAL}_{i} \cdot \text{dur}_{i} \cdot \text{rate}_{i} \cdot \text{stress}_{(i, \text{up})} - \sum_{\text{lob}} \text{BE}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{dur}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{rate}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{stress}_{(\text{lob}, \text{up})}
$$

where:
(a)(a) the first sum covers all maturity intervals _i_ set out in paragraph 4 of this Article;


(b) _MVAL_ _i_ denotes the value in accordance with Article 75 of Directive 2009/138/EC of assets less liabilities other than
technical provisions for maturity interval _i_ ;


(c) _dur_ _i_ denotes the simplified duration of maturity interval _i_ ;


(d) _rate_ _i_ denotes the relevant risk-free rate for the simplified duration of maturity interval _i_ ;


(e) _stress_ _(i,up)_ denotes the relative upward stress of interest rate for simplified duration of maturity interval _i_ ;


(f) the second sum covers all lines of business set out in Annex I of this Regulation;


(g) _BE_ _lob_ denotes the best estimate for line of business _lob_ ;


(h) _dur_ _lob_ denotes the modified duration of the best estimate in line of business _lob_ ;


(i) _rate_ _lob_ denotes the relevant risk-free rate for modified duration in line of business _lob_ ; 



### source 2 

 metadata:
 * Title: COMMISSION  DELEGATED  REGULATION  (EU)  2015/  35  -  of  10  October  2014  -  supplementing  Directive  2009/  138/  EC  of  the  European  Parliament  and  of  the  Council  on  the  taking-up  and  pursuit  of  the  business  of  Insurance  and  Reinsurance  (Solvency  II)
* Header 1: TITLE I

* Header 2: *CHAPTER V*

* Header 3: Section 1

* Header 4: Subsection 6

* Header 5: Article 103
:

 extract:

 **Simplified calculation of the capital requirement for interest rate risk for captive insurance or reinsurance**
**undertakings**


1. Where Articles 88 and 89 are complied with, captive insurance or captive reinsurance undertakings may calculate
the capital requirement for interest rate risk referred to in Article 165 as follows:


(a) the sum, for each currency, of the capital requirements for the risk of an increase in the term structure of interest
rates as set out in paragraph 2 of this Article;


(b) the sum, for each currency, of the capital requirements for the risk of a decrease in the term structure of interest
rates as set out in paragraph 3 of this Article.


2. For the purposes of point (a) of paragraph 1 of this Article, the capital requirement for the risk of an increase in
the term structure of interest rates for a given currency shall be equal to the following:

$$
\text{IR}_{\text{up}} = \sum_{i} \text{MVAL}_{i} \cdot \text{dur}_{i} \cdot \text{rate}_{i} \cdot \text{stress}_{(i, \text{up})} - \sum_{\text{lob}} \text{BE}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{dur}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{rate}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{stress}_{(\text{lob}, \text{up})}
$$ 



### source 3 

 metadata:
 * Title: COMMISSION  DELEGATED  REGULATION  (EU)  2015/  35  -  of  10  October  2014  -  supplementing  Directive  2009/  138/  EC  of  the  European  Parliament  and  of  the  Council  on  the  taking-up  and  pursuit  of  the  business  of  Insurance  and  Reinsurance  (Solvency  II)
* Header 1: TITLE I

* Header 2: *CHAPTER V*

* Header 3: Section 5

* Header 4: Subsection 2

* Header 5: Article 165
:

 extract:

 (a) the sum, over all currencies, of the capital requirements for the risk of an increase in the term structure of interest
rates as set out in Article 166 of this Regulation;


(b) the sum, over all currencies, of the capital requirements for the risk of a decrease in the term structure of interest
rates as set out in Article 167 of this Regulation.

2. Where the larger of the capital requirements referred to in points (a) and (b) of paragraph 1 and the larger of the
corresponding capital requirements calculated in accordance with Article 206(2) are not based on the same scenario, the
capital requirement for interest rate risk shall be the capital requirement referred to in points (a) or (b) of paragraph 1
for which the underlying scenario results in the largest corresponding capital requirement calculated in accordance with
Article 206(2). 



### source 4 

 metadata:
 * Title: COMMISSION  DELEGATED  REGULATION  (EU)  2015/  35  -  of  10  October  2014  -  supplementing  Directive  2009/  138/  EC  of  the  European  Parliament  and  of  the  Council  on  the  taking-up  and  pursuit  of  the  business  of  Insurance  and  Reinsurance  (Solvency  II)
* Header 1: TITLE I

* Header 2: *CHAPTER V*
:

 extract:

 **SOLVENCY CAPITAL REQUIREMENT STANDARD FORMULA** 



### source 5 

 metadata:
 * Title: Directive 2009/138/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 November 2009 on the taking-up and pursuit of the business of Insurance and Reinsurance (Solvency II)
* Header 1: _ANNEX IV_
:

 extract:

 **SOLVENCY CAPITAL REQUIREMENT (SCR) STANDARD FORMULA**


1. **Calculation of the Basic Solvency Capital Requirement**


The Basic Solvency Capital Requirement set out in Article 104(1) shall be equal to the following:

$$
\text{Basic SCR} = \sqrt{\sum_{i,j} \text{Corr}_{i,j} \times \text{SCR}_{i} \times \text{SCR}_{j}}
$$


where SCR i denotes the risk module i and SCR j denotes the risk module j, and where ‘i,j’ means that the sum of the dif­
ferent terms should cover all possible combinations of i and j. In the calculation, SCR i and SCR j are replaced by the
following:


— SCR non-life denotes the non-life underwriting risk module,


— SCR life denotes the life underwriting risk module,


— SCR health denotes the health underwriting risk module,


— SCR market denotes the market risk module,


— SCR default denotes the counterparty default risk module,


The factor Corr i,j denotes the item set out in row i and in column j of the following correlation matrix:




<image>
A header row for a table or matrix with row index 'i' and column index 'j'. The columns are labeled Market, Default, Life, Health, and Non-life, likely representing different risk categories in finance or insurance.
i
j
Market
Default
Life
Health
Non-life
</image>






Market 1 0,25 0,25 0,25 0,25


Default 0,25 1 0,25 0,25 0,5 


 


        
## Answer
        

 When answering reference ONLY if applicable source with (Source <insert number>). Answer based on the mentioned sources in the Context answer the Question.

sources.page_content:
**Simplified calculation of the capital requirement for interest rate risk for captive insurance or reinsurance**
**undertakings**


1. Where Articles 88 and 89 are complied with, captive insurance or captive reinsurance undertakings may calculate
the capital requirement for interest rate risk referred to in Article 165 as follows:


(a) the sum, for each currency, of the capital requirements for the risk of an increase in the term structure of interest
rates as set out in paragraph 2 of this Article;


(b) the sum, for each currency, of the capital requirements for the risk of a decrease in the term structure of interest
rates as set out in paragraph 3 of this Article.


2. For the purposes of point (a) of paragraph 1 of this Article, the capital requirement for the risk of an increase in
the term structure of interest rates for a given currency shall be equal to the following:

$$
\text{IR}_{\text{up}} = \sum_{i} \text{MVAL}_{i} \cdot \text{dur}_{i} \cdot \text{rate}_{i} \cdot \text{stress}_{(i, \text{up})} - \sum_{\text{lob}} \text{BE}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{dur}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{rate}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{stress}_{(\text{lob}, \text{up})}
$$

rates as set out in Article 167 of this Regulation.

2. Where the larger of the capital requirements referred to in points (a) and (b) of paragraph 1 and the larger of the
corresponding capital requirements calculated in accordance with Article 206(2) are not based on the same scenario, the
capital requirement for interest rate risk shall be the capital requirement referred to in points (a) or (b) of paragraph 1
for which the underlying scenario results in the largest corresponding capital requirement calculated in accordance with
Article 206(2).

**SOLVENCY CAPITAL REQUIREMENT (SCR) STANDARD FORMULA**


1. **Calculation of the Basic Solvency Capital Requirement**


The Basic Solvency Capital Requirement set out in Article 104(1) shall be equal to the following:

$$
\text{Basic SCR} = \sqrt{\sum_{i,j} \text{Corr}_{i,j} \times \text{SCR}_{i} \times \text{SCR}_{j}}
$$


where SCR i denotes the risk module i and SCR j denotes the risk module j, and where ‘i,j’ means that the sum of the dif­
ferent terms should cover all possible combinations of i and j. In the calculation, SCR i and SCR j are replaced by the
following:

sources.query: Wat zijn de de up en down renteschokken onder de standaard formule SCR interest rate risk?

content: Op basis van de verstrekte bronnen wordt de kapitaalvereiste voor renterisico (SCR interest rate risk) onder de standaardformule berekend door de impact van twee scenario's te bepalen: 1. **Een renteschok omhoog (up shock)**: Dit is het risico van een stijging van de rentetermijnstructuur (). De berekening voor deze schok wordt als volgt weergegeven: $$ \text{IR}_{\text{up}} = \sum_{i} \text{MVAL}_{i} \cdot \text{dur}_{i} \cdot \text{rate}_{i} \cdot \text{stress}_{(i, \text{up})} - \sum_{\text{lob}} \text{BE}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{dur}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{rate}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{stress}_{(\text{lob}, \text{up})} $$ Hierin staat `stress_(i, up)` voor de relatieve opwaartse rentestress voor een bepaalde looptijd (). 2. **Een renteschok omlaag (down shock)**: Dit is het risico van een daling van de rentetermijnstructuur (). De kapitaalvereiste voor renterisico is de grootste van de kapitaalvereisten die uit deze twee scenario's voortvloeien (). De verstrekte bronnen beschrijven de methodologie en de formules voor het berekenen van de impact van deze schokken, maar specificeren niet de exacte percentages van de up- en down-schokken zelf.
content_unformatted:
Op basis van de verstrekte bronnen wordt de kapitaalvereiste voor renterisico (SCR interest rate risk) onder de standaardformule berekend door de impact van twee scenario's te bepalen:

1.  **Een renteschok omhoog (up shock)**: Dit is het risico van een stijging van de rentetermijnstructuur (Source 3). De berekening voor deze schok wordt als volgt weergegeven:
    $$
    \text{IR}_{\text{up}} = \sum_{i} \text{MVAL}_{i} \cdot \text{dur}_{i} \cdot \text{rate}_{i} \cdot \text{stress}_{(i, \text{up})} - \sum_{\text{lob}} \text{BE}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{dur}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{rate}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{stress}_{(\text{lob}, \text{up})}
    $$
    Hierin staat `stress_(i, up)` voor de relatieve opwaartse rentestress voor een bepaalde looptijd (Source 1, Source 2).

2.  **Een renteschok omlaag (down shock)**: Dit is het risico van een daling van de rentetermijnstructuur (Source 3).

De kapitaalvereiste voor renterisico is de grootste van de kapitaalvereisten die uit deze twee scenario's voortvloeien (Source 3).

De verstrekte bronnen beschrijven de methodologie en de formules voor het berekenen van de impact van deze schokken, maar specificeren niet de exacte percentages van de up- en down-schokken zelf.
popover_elements:
Solvency II – Level 2 Regulation

TITLE I > CHAPTER V > Section 5 > Subsection 2 > Article 165

(a) the sum, over all currencies, of the capital requirements for the risk of an increase in the term structure of interest rates as set out in Article 166 of this Regulation;

(b) the sum, over all currencies, of the capital requirements for the risk of a decrease in the term structure of interest rates as set out in Article 167 of this Regulation.

  1. Where the larger of the capital requirements referred to in points (a) and (b) of paragraph 1 and the larger of the corresponding capital requirements calculated in accordance with Article 206(2) are not based on the same scenario, the capital requirement for interest rate risk shall be the capital requirement referred to in points (a) or (b) of paragraph 1 for which the underlying scenario results in the largest corresponding capital requirement calculated in accordance with Article 206(2).

Solvency II – Level 2 Regulation

TITLE I > CHAPTER V > Section 1 > Subsection 6 > Article 103

\text{IR}_{\text{up}} = \sum_{i} \text{MVAL}_{i} \cdot \text{dur}_{i} \cdot \text{rate}_{i} \cdot \text{stress}_{(i, \text{up})} - \sum_{\text{lob}} \text{BE}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{dur}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{rate}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{stress}_{(\text{lob}, \text{up})}

where: (a)(a) the first sum covers all maturity intervals i set out in paragraph 4 of this Article;

(b) MVAL i denotes the value in accordance with Article 75 of Directive 2009/138/EC of assets less liabilities other than technical provisions for maturity interval i ;

(c) dur i denotes the simplified duration of maturity interval i ;

(d) rate i denotes the relevant risk-free rate for the simplified duration of maturity interval i ;

(e) stress (i,up) denotes the relative upward stress of interest rate for simplified duration of maturity interval i ;

(f) the second sum covers all lines of business set out in Annex I of this Regulation;

(g) BE lob denotes the best estimate for line of business lob ;

(h) dur lob denotes the modified duration of the best estimate in line of business lob ;

(i) rate lob denotes the relevant risk-free rate for modified duration in line of business lob ;

Solvency II – Level 2 Regulation

TITLE I > CHAPTER V > Section 1 > Subsection 6 > Article 103

Simplified calculation of the capital requirement for interest rate risk for captive insurance or reinsurance undertakings

  1. Where Articles 88 and 89 are complied with, captive insurance or captive reinsurance undertakings may calculate the capital requirement for interest rate risk referred to in Article 165 as follows:

(a) the sum, for each currency, of the capital requirements for the risk of an increase in the term structure of interest rates as set out in paragraph 2 of this Article;

(b) the sum, for each currency, of the capital requirements for the risk of a decrease in the term structure of interest rates as set out in paragraph 3 of this Article.

  1. For the purposes of point (a) of paragraph 1 of this Article, the capital requirement for the risk of an increase in the term structure of interest rates for a given currency shall be equal to the following:
\text{IR}_{\text{up}} = \sum_{i} \text{MVAL}_{i} \cdot \text{dur}_{i} \cdot \text{rate}_{i} \cdot \text{stress}_{(i, \text{up})} - \sum_{\text{lob}} \text{BE}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{dur}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{rate}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{stress}_{(\text{lob}, \text{up})}

Solvency II – Level 2 Regulation

TITLE I > CHAPTER V > Section 5 > Subsection 2 > Article 165

(a) the sum, over all currencies, of the capital requirements for the risk of an increase in the term structure of interest rates as set out in Article 166 of this Regulation;

(b) the sum, over all currencies, of the capital requirements for the risk of a decrease in the term structure of interest rates as set out in Article 167 of this Regulation.

  1. Where the larger of the capital requirements referred to in points (a) and (b) of paragraph 1 and the larger of the corresponding capital requirements calculated in accordance with Article 206(2) are not based on the same scenario, the capital requirement for interest rate risk shall be the capital requirement referred to in points (a) or (b) of paragraph 1 for which the underlying scenario results in the largest corresponding capital requirement calculated in accordance with Article 206(2).

Solvency II – Level 2 Regulation

TITLE I > CHAPTER V > Section 5 > Subsection 2 > Article 165

(a) the sum, over all currencies, of the capital requirements for the risk of an increase in the term structure of interest rates as set out in Article 166 of this Regulation;

(b) the sum, over all currencies, of the capital requirements for the risk of a decrease in the term structure of interest rates as set out in Article 167 of this Regulation.

  1. Where the larger of the capital requirements referred to in points (a) and (b) of paragraph 1 and the larger of the corresponding capital requirements calculated in accordance with Article 206(2) are not based on the same scenario, the capital requirement for interest rate risk shall be the capital requirement referred to in points (a) or (b) of paragraph 1 for which the underlying scenario results in the largest corresponding capital requirement calculated in accordance with Article 206(2).
thoughts:
**Focusing Interest Rate Risk**

I've homed in on the user's core inquiry: they want to understand the interest rate shocks, both positive and negative, used in the Solvency Capital Requirement's standard formula for interest rate risk. I'm now actively searching through the provided resources, specifically hunting for those critical terms: "interest rate risk," "SCR," "standard formula," and "up shock."


**Investigating Shock Values**

Now, I'm trying to decipher the specific values used for the upward and downward interest rate shocks within the standard formula. While Sources 1 and 2 detail the calculation methodology, they omit the concrete shock percentages. Source 3, Article 165, mentions a general capital requirement but doesn't offer these specific figures. I'm now cross-referencing this article to see if any supplementary documents or annexes might contain this key information.


**Delineating Shock Parameters**

I've determined that Sources 1, 2, and 5 all outline the methodology but don't explicitly state the shock percentages. Source 3 hints at Articles 166 and 167 as key. I'm now certain I need those articles to find the numerical values for the "up" and "down" interest rate shocks within the standard formula. I'll need to expand my search to locate those critical articles.


**Determining Shock Percentages**

I've got the lay of the land now. I'm focusing on those crucial shock percentages. The Solvency Capital Requirement's standard formula relies on "up" and "down" shocks, and the existing sources show me how to calculate the capital impact of those shocks, but they *don't* show me the values. I need those Articles 166 and 167. I know that Article 165 points to them for those shock parameters. I am going to try to identify any documents, links, or resources that would provide me with these critical missing pieces.


**Determining Missing Parameters**

Okay, the path is clear. Articles 166 and 167 are the golden tickets! I've confirmed that the given sources detail the method but leave out the precise percentages for both interest rate shocks. I'm now certain I need to get my hands on those two missing articles to have all the components of the standard formula. My focus is now on locating those crucial, missing values.

content: Wat zijn de relatieve opwaartse en neerwaartste stresschokken onder de standaard formule?
prompt:
## Question
        

 Wat zijn de relatieve opwaartse en neerwaartste stresschokken onder de standaard formule? 


        
## Context
        

 
### source 1 

 metadata:
 * Title: COMMISSION  DELEGATED  REGULATION  (EU)  2015/  35  -  of  10  October  2014  -  supplementing  Directive  2009/  138/  EC  of  the  European  Parliament  and  of  the  Council  on  the  taking-up  and  pursuit  of  the  business  of  Insurance  and  Reinsurance  (Solvency  II)
* Header 1: TITLE I

* Header 2: *CHAPTER V*

* Header 3: Section 1

* Header 4: Subsection 6

* Header 5: Article 103
:

 extract:

 $$
\text{IR}_{\text{up}} = \sum_{i} \text{MVAL}_{i} \cdot \text{dur}_{i} \cdot \text{rate}_{i} \cdot \text{stress}_{(i, \text{up})} - \sum_{\text{lob}} \text{BE}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{dur}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{rate}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{stress}_{(\text{lob}, \text{up})}
$$

where:
(a)(a) the first sum covers all maturity intervals _i_ set out in paragraph 4 of this Article;


(b) _MVAL_ _i_ denotes the value in accordance with Article 75 of Directive 2009/138/EC of assets less liabilities other than
technical provisions for maturity interval _i_ ;


(c) _dur_ _i_ denotes the simplified duration of maturity interval _i_ ;


(d) _rate_ _i_ denotes the relevant risk-free rate for the simplified duration of maturity interval _i_ ;


(e) _stress_ _(i,up)_ denotes the relative upward stress of interest rate for simplified duration of maturity interval _i_ ;


(f) the second sum covers all lines of business set out in Annex I of this Regulation;


(g) _BE_ _lob_ denotes the best estimate for line of business _lob_ ;


(h) _dur_ _lob_ denotes the modified duration of the best estimate in line of business _lob_ ;


(i) _rate_ _lob_ denotes the relevant risk-free rate for modified duration in line of business _lob_ ;

### source 4 

 metadata:
 * Title: COMMISSION  DELEGATED  REGULATION  (EU)  2015/  35  -  of  10  October  2014  -  supplementing  Directive  2009/  138/  EC  of  the  European  Parliament  and  of  the  Council  on  the  taking-up  and  pursuit  of  the  business  of  Insurance  and  Reinsurance  (Solvency  II)
* Header 1: TITLE I

* Header 2: *CHAPTER III*

* Header 3: Section 4

* Header 4: Subsection 4

* Header 5: Article 52
:

 extract:

 **Mortality risk stress**


1. The mortality risk stress referred to in Article 77b(1)(f) of Directive 2009/138/EC shall be the more adverse of the
following two scenarios in terms of its impact on basic own funds:


(a) an instantaneous permanent increase of 15 % in the mortality rates used for the calculation of the best estimate;


(b) an instantaneous increase of 0.15 percentage points in the mortality rates (expressed as percentages) which are used
in the calculation of technical provisions to reflect the mortality experience in the following 12 months.


2. For the purpose of paragraph 1 the increase in mortality rates shall only apply to those insurance policies for
which the increase in mortality rates leads to an increase in technical provisions taking into account all of the following:


(a) multiple insurance policies in respect of the same insured person may be treated as if they were one insurance
policy; 



### source 5 

 metadata:
 * Title: guidelines-level-3: Guidelines on undertaking-specific parameters.pdf:

 extract:

 1.2. The Guidelines relate to Article 104(7), 110, 111, 230, 248(2) of Directive/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 November
2009 on the taking up and pursuit of the business of Insurance and Reinsurance
(hereinafter “Solvency II”) [2] as well as to Articles 218, 219, 220, 338 and 356 of
Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2015/35 of 10 October 2014
supplementing Directive 2009/138/EC (hereinafter Commission Delegated
Regulation 2015/35) [3] .


1.3. These Guidelines are addressed to supervisory authorities under Solvency II.


1.4. When calculating the Solvency Capital Requirement, undertakings may replace
a subset of parameters (standard parameters) within the standard formula by
parameters specific to them, if the standard formula does not provide an
appropriate representation of their underlying risks. This should help to
promote sound risk management within insurance and reinsurance
undertakings. 


 


        
## Answer
        

 When answering reference ONLY if applicable source with (Source <insert number>). Answer based on the mentioned sources in the Context answer the Question.

sources.page_content:
**Mortality risk stress**


1. The mortality risk stress referred to in Article 77b(1)(f) of Directive 2009/138/EC shall be the more adverse of the
following two scenarios in terms of its impact on basic own funds:


(a) an instantaneous permanent increase of 15 % in the mortality rates used for the calculation of the best estimate;


(b) an instantaneous increase of 0.15 percentage points in the mortality rates (expressed as percentages) which are used
in the calculation of technical provisions to reflect the mortality experience in the following 12 months.


2. For the purpose of paragraph 1 the increase in mortality rates shall only apply to those insurance policies for
which the increase in mortality rates leads to an increase in technical provisions taking into account all of the following:


(a) multiple insurance policies in respect of the same insured person may be treated as if they were one insurance
policy;
sources.query: Wat zijn de relatieve opwaartse en neerwaartste stresschokken onder de standaard formule?

sources.title: guidelines-level-3: Guidelines on undertaking-specific parameters.pdf
sources.page_content:
1.2. The Guidelines relate to Article 104(7), 110, 111, 230, 248(2) of Directive/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 November
2009 on the taking up and pursuit of the business of Insurance and Reinsurance
(hereinafter “Solvency II”) [2] as well as to Articles 218, 219, 220, 338 and 356 of
Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2015/35 of 10 October 2014
supplementing Directive 2009/138/EC (hereinafter Commission Delegated
Regulation 2015/35) [3] .


1.3. These Guidelines are addressed to supervisory authorities under Solvency II.


1.4. When calculating the Solvency Capital Requirement, undertakings may replace
a subset of parameters (standard parameters) within the standard formula by
parameters specific to them, if the standard formula does not provide an
appropriate representation of their underlying risks. This should help to
promote sound risk management within insurance and reinsurance
undertakings.
sources.query: Wat zijn de relatieve opwaartse en neerwaartste stresschokken onder de standaard formule?

content: Op basis van de verstrekte documenten kan ik geen antwoord geven op de vraag wat de specifieke percentages zijn voor de relatieve opwaartse en neerwaartse stresschokken. De bronnen bevestigen het bestaan van een "relative upward stress of interest rate" (aangeduid als `stress_(i, up)`) als onderdeel van de standaardformule voor het berekenen van de kapitaalvereiste voor een rentestijging, maar de concrete waarde of het percentage wordt niet genoemd ().
content_unformatted:
Op basis van de verstrekte documenten kan ik geen antwoord geven op de vraag wat de specifieke percentages zijn voor de relatieve opwaartse en neerwaartse stresschokken.

De bronnen bevestigen het bestaan van een "relative upward stress of interest rate" (aangeduid als `stress_(i, up)`) als onderdeel van de standaardformule voor het berekenen van de kapitaalvereiste voor een rentestijging, maar de concrete waarde of het percentage wordt niet genoemd (Source 1).
popover_elements:
Solvency II – Level 2 Regulation

TITLE I > CHAPTER V > Section 1 > Subsection 6 > Article 103

\text{IR}_{\text{up}} = \sum_{i} \text{MVAL}_{i} \cdot \text{dur}_{i} \cdot \text{rate}_{i} \cdot \text{stress}_{(i, \text{up})} - \sum_{\text{lob}} \text{BE}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{dur}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{rate}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{stress}_{(\text{lob}, \text{up})}

where: (a)(a) the first sum covers all maturity intervals i set out in paragraph 4 of this Article;

(b) MVAL i denotes the value in accordance with Article 75 of Directive 2009/138/EC of assets less liabilities other than technical provisions for maturity interval i ;

(c) dur i denotes the simplified duration of maturity interval i ;

(d) rate i denotes the relevant risk-free rate for the simplified duration of maturity interval i ;

(e) stress (i,up) denotes the relative upward stress of interest rate for simplified duration of maturity interval i ;

(f) the second sum covers all lines of business set out in Annex I of this Regulation;

(g) BE lob denotes the best estimate for line of business lob ;

(h) dur lob denotes the modified duration of the best estimate in line of business lob ;

(i) rate lob denotes the relevant risk-free rate for modified duration in line of business lob ;

content: Op basis van de verstrekte bronnen is het niet mogelijk om de relatieve opwaartse en neerwaartste stresschokken voor het algemene renterisico te bepalen. De tabellen in de bronnen () komen uit Artikel 180 van de Gedelegeerde Verordening. Deze tabellen specificeren de stressfactor (`stress_i`) voor het **spreadrisico** op obligaties en leningen, niet voor het algemene renterisico (veranderingen in de risicovrije rentecurve). De stressfactor voor spreadrisico is afhankelijk van de kredietkwaliteit ("Credit quality step") en de duratie van de activa. toont wel de formule voor de kapitaalvereiste bij een rentestijging (`IR_up`), waarin de term `stress_(i, up)` wordt gebruikt om de "relatieve opwaartse stress van de rente" aan te duiden, maar de specifieke waarden of de bijbehorende tabel voor deze stressfactor zijn niet in de verstrekte documenten opgenomen.
content_unformatted:
Op basis van de verstrekte bronnen is het niet mogelijk om de relatieve opwaartse en neerwaartste stresschokken voor het algemene renterisico te bepalen.

De tabellen in de bronnen (Source 2, Source 3) komen uit Artikel 180 van de Gedelegeerde Verordening. Deze tabellen specificeren de stressfactor (`stress_i`) voor het **spreadrisico** op obligaties en leningen, niet voor het algemene renterisico (veranderingen in de risicovrije rentecurve). De stressfactor voor spreadrisico is afhankelijk van de kredietkwaliteit ("Credit quality step") en de duratie van de activa.

Bron 1 toont wel de formule voor de kapitaalvereiste bij een rentestijging (`IR_up`), waarin de term `stress_(i, up)` wordt gebruikt om de "relatieve opwaartse stress van de rente" aan te duiden, maar de specifieke waarden of de bijbehorende tabel voor deze stressfactor zijn niet in de verstrekte documenten opgenomen.

Solvency ratio 196 % 175 % 122 % 95 % 75 % 75 %
Credit quality step 1 2 3 4 5 6

Solvency II – Level 2 Regulation

TITLE I > CHAPTER V > Section 5 > Subsection 5 > Article 180

  1. Exposures in the form of bonds and loans to an insurance or reinsurance undertaking which does not meet its Minimum Capital Requirement shall be assigned a risk factor stress i according to the following table:
Duration (dur)
i		 risk factor stress
i
up to 5 7,5 %._duri _
More than 5 and up to 10 37,50 % + 4,20 %.(_duri _– 5)
More than 10 and up to 15 58,50 % + 0,50 %.(_duri _– 10)
More than 15 and up to 20 61 % + 0,50 %.(_duri _– 15)
More than 20 minð63,5% þ 0,5%  ð_duri_ − 20Þ; 1Þ
  1. Paragraphs 4 and 5 of this Article shall only apply as of the first date of public disclosure, by the undertaking corresponding to the exposure, of the report on its solvency and financial condition referred to in Article 51 of Directive 2009/138/EC. Before that date, if a credit assessment by a nominated ECAI is available for the exposures, Article 176 of this Regulation shall apply, otherwise, the exposures shall be assigned the same risk factor as the ones that would result from the application of paragraph 4 of this Article to exposures to an insurance or reinsurance undertaking whose solvency ratio is 100 %.

Solvency II – Level 2 Regulation

TITLE I > CHAPTER V > Section 1 > Subsection 6 > Article 103

\text{IR}_{\text{up}} = \sum_{i} \text{MVAL}_{i} \cdot \text{dur}_{i} \cdot \text{rate}_{i} \cdot \text{stress}_{(i, \text{up})} - \sum_{\text{lob}} \text{BE}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{dur}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{rate}_{\text{lob}} \cdot \text{stress}_{(\text{lob}, \text{up})}

where: (a)(a) the first sum covers all maturity intervals i set out in paragraph 4 of this Article;

(b) MVAL i denotes the value in accordance with Article 75 of Directive 2009/138/EC of assets less liabilities other than technical provisions for maturity interval i ;

(c) dur i denotes the simplified duration of maturity interval i ;

(d) rate i denotes the relevant risk-free rate for the simplified duration of maturity interval i ;

(e) stress (i,up) denotes the relative upward stress of interest rate for simplified duration of maturity interval i ;

(f) the second sum covers all lines of business set out in Annex I of this Regulation;

(g) BE lob denotes the best estimate for line of business lob ;

(h) dur lob denotes the modified duration of the best estimate in line of business lob ;

(i) rate lob denotes the relevant risk-free rate for modified duration in line of business lob ;
